ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was able to learn the basic concepts of graphic design and actually discover what I'm capable of through numerous projects.

I learned about the elements that come together to create successful pieces of design. I learned how to make compositions, posters, typography, and booklets, while also gaining the ability to talk about not just my own art, but art of others, too (critiques, for example).
spacing of elements, intro to typography, intro to color combinations, collage making, presentation of work
I learned basic design skills and the design process
I learned basic elements of design and skills for designing a project.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: 
Getting to see all the high quality design art pieces that he picked out from historical designers were very helpful in developing creativity and critical eyes.
Having an opportunity to see other students' work was very helpful and inspiring. It was very interesting to see what people come up with from same topic and theme. 

Weakness: 
It would have been more helpful if we were able to see art works of students from other section.

This course was incredible. I enjoyed talking about work with my peers, while hearing Henk's feedback, as well. I think it was organized quite well, especially for an art class held over Zoom. However, I sometimes wish we gained more instruction and knowledge through lectures (even if they are on the shorter end) or demonstrations.

Strengths: class size, regular verbal feedback, variety of projects, lots of interactions with peers and prof 

Weaknesses: registrar/department charged students $150 supplies fee despite the semester being remote (no supplies/resources were provided by the course despite this fee charge...quite unreasonable), workload was super off-balanced (super heavy during first month/two), course materials are expensive, no formal assessment results all semester (closest thing was a two week late midterm check-in)

The projects were very fun to do. The first set of formal exercises took more time than anticipated because they were hands on, but they were very rewarding in the end. Sadly, the limitations were that the course was virtual, and we were unable to interact with other students as much.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I felt that screen sharing the art work was successful, and using chat boxes to comment on each other's work was also successful. Professor scribbling on shared screen was also helpful to have us visually know where he wants us to revise. 
Using google drive to submit our art works was also successful and efficient.

I think going around the "Zoom room" for critiques was successful. However, of course, it becomes less engaging to just type feedback into the chat box, but I'm not sure if there's a way to get around that.

Most practices were fine given the COVID-19 pandemic. The only issue is that students were charged $150 for nothing... no supplies, no additional resources, no additional learning experiences. Please refund students the $150 supplies fee. To be clear, this is a registrar/department issue and NOT Henk's responsibility.
Presenting the work via screen sharing was effective.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It'll make you use other parts of your brain, and you'll be able to train your creativity in this course. The work load is very intense the first 1/4 of the course, but the work load will become more doable towards the end of the course. Seeing other student's art work is very inspiring and challenges you to excel more.

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Even if you're not majoring in art, or have any experience with art, this course changes the way you look at design. Whether it's promotional content, billboards, magazine covers, posters, etc., I've developed the skills and knowledge to look at things, and truly analyze whether or not its design was effective, and how it could be improved. In addition, you'll learn how to communicate through design, which is an important skill to have regardless of what career path you may choose to take.
Yes for those with the time availability
Yes. I learned how to get a better eye for design elements, and the projects were challenging, but fun to complete.
